question: <image 1> A company wants to evaluate its attrition rate, in other words, how long new hires stay with the company. Over the years, they have established the following probability distribution. Let X = the number of years a new hire will stay with the company. Let P(x) = the probability that a new hire will stay with the company x years. P(x = 4) = _______
description:
The image shows a table with two columns. The first column is labeled "x," which represents the number of years a new hire will stay with the company. The second column is labeled "P(x)," which represents the probability that a new hire will stay with the company for x years. The table lists the following values:

- For x = 0, P(x) = 0.12
- For x = 1, P(x) = 0.18
- For x = 2, P(x) = 0.30
- For x = 3, P(x) = 0.15
- For x = 4, P(x) = 0.10
- For x = 5, P(x) = 0.05

The value for P(x = 4) is 0.10.
